profileText: A Delegate from Pennsylvania; born in New Castle, Del., May 10, 1730; completed preparatory studies; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1750 and commenced practice in Lancaster, Pa.; member of the colonial assembly 1768-1776; delegate to the state convention in 1774; Member of the Continental Congress 1774-1777; a signer of the Declaration of Independence; appointed judge of the court of admiralty for Pennsylvania in April 1779 and served in that capacity until his death near Philadelphia, Pa., July 14, 1779; interment in Christ Church Burying Ground, Philadelphia, Pa.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ross, George. Pamphlets, broadsides, clippings, and other miscellaneous matter on this subject, not separately catalogued. [N.p., N.d.]

researchRecord.name: 1779, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from George Ross to his son, George, written on March 25, 1779. In the letter, George Ross writes concerning the difficulties of Mr. Loyd.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1776, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: A court order from George Ross, as judge of the Admiralty Court of Pennsylvania, orders Philadelphia marshall Matthew Clarkson to summon a jury to the Court of Admiralty to try a case involving James Campbell of the privateer "Enterprise" and George Corrie of the "Black River." An engraving of George Ross J.W. Steel from the original picture accompanies the court order.
